spartan
  • spartan
    • A spartan bioinformatics package, providing only the essentials and nothing fancy or luxurious. Enough to get the job done quickly without flourish.
  • Installation
    • Requirements
    • Installing the latest version from the git repository
    • Use pip to obtain the package from PyPI
    • Installing without using git or pip for the download
    • Test to see whether the install worked

files.py¶

class spartan.utils.files.ParseFastA(filePath, joinWith='', key=None)[source]¶

Returns a record-by-record fastA parser analogous to file.readline().

__init__(filePath, joinWith='', key=None)[source]¶

Returns a record-by-record fastA parser analogous to file.readline(). Exmpl: parser.next() Its ALSO an iterator so “for rec in parser” works too!

<joinWith> is string to use to join rec lines with. joinWith=’’ results in a single line with no breaks (usually what you want!)

<key> is func used to parse the recName from HeaderInfo.

next()[source]¶

Reads in next element, parses, and does minimal verification. Returns: tuple: (seqName,seqStr)

rewrite_headers(outPath, lineLen=70, delim=' ', order=, []ow=False, chmod=755)[source]¶

PURPOSE * reorganize the headers of a fasta file:

>supercontig:CpipQ1:supercont3.1:1:3873040:1 supercontig supercont3.1 to >supercont3.1 supercontig:CpipQ1:supercont3.1:1:3873040:1 supercontig

NOTES 1) If ow, ignores outPath 2) delim is what to spilt on 3) order is a list of index numbers from the original header, reorganized for the new header.

Exp: delim=’ ‘,order=[2,0,1] would produce what is seen above.
  1. chmod= set new file with this mode (exp: 755)
  2. lineLen sets fastaSeq line length in new file.
to_dict()[source]¶

Returns a single Dict populated with the fastaRecs contained in self._file.

class spartan.utils.files.ParseFastQ(filePath, headerSymbols=['@', '+'])[source]¶

Returns a read-by-read fastQ parser analogous to file.readline()

__init__(filePath, headerSymbols=['@', '+'])[source]¶

Returns a read-by-read fastQ parser analogous to file.readline(). Exmpl: parser.next() -OR- Its an iterator so you can do: for rec in parser:

... do something with rec ...

rec is tuple: (seqHeader,seqStr,qualHeader,qualStr)

Iterates through a single-end fastQ file and writes only those recs that satisfy the <key> lambda func to <filteredPath>.

spartan.utils.files.fastaRec_length_indexer(fastaFiles)[source]¶

GIVEN: 1) fastaFiles: list of fasta files or dirs containing fasta files

DO: 1) iterate through all fasta files recording recName and length to a dict

RETURN: 1) dict with recName and lengths

NOTES: 1) will complain if it sees more than one fastaRec with the same name ONLY

if one of the length values disagrees with those already seen.
spartan.utils.files.filter_PEfastQs(filterFunc, fwdMatePath, revMatePath, matchedPassPath1, matchedPassPath2, singlePassPath, nonPassPath)[source]¶

Takes the paths to mated PE fastq files with coordinated read-ordering. Tests whether paired reads satisfy the provided filterFunc. :param filterFunc: :param fwdMatePath: :param revMatePath: :param matchedPassPath1: :param matchedPassPath2: :param singlePassPath: :param nonPassPath: For example fastQs from hudsonAlpha should have either “Y” or “N” flag in their header:

@HWI-ST619:70:B0BMTABXX:3:1102:9652:78621 1:N:0:TAGCTT GAATGCGATAGTCACAAGGCATGCCGTTGAATATTCGCAACTGAGCTTCG + @@@?DAD;DADAD:EGAGH=CFEEHB?GIEBFBGI@CFGD@FG>>@GGGH

The fastQ parsers represent each read as a 4 member list with each line’s data as an index.

The filterFunc for this case might be: lambda x: x[0].split(‘ ‘)[-1].split(‘:’)[1] == “N”

If both mates satisfy the filter, the fwd mate is written to matchedPassPath1 and rev mate to matchedPassPath2. If only one mate satisfies the filter, it is written to singlePassPath regardles of fwd/rev. All reads that do not satisfy the filter are written to nonPassPath.

Notes: * The filterFunc does not have to be a simple lambda, but even something like “testMeanQualScore()”,

as long as it returns a True/False with True meaning that the read should be KEPT.
  • Write-files are overwritten if they exist, created otherwise.
spartan.utils.files.mv_file_obj(fileObj, newPath='', chmod=False)[source]¶

GIVEN: 1) fileObj: file object to be moved 2) newPath: new path (if not abs path, current working dir is used)

MUST at LEAST include a name for new file.
  1. chmod: string to use for new file permissions (if False: no change).

DO: 1) fileObj.flush() 2) use shutil.move(src,dest) to move file location. 3) change fileObj.name to the new name. 4) if file is tmpFile, make sure fileObj.delete == False

(I assume that if you care enough to move the file, you want to keep it)
  1. chmod on new file to set permissions (remember to use octal: 0755 NOT 755)

RETURN: 1) fileObj

spartan.utils.files.onlyInA(fileA, fileB, outFile)[source]¶

Takes two files. Writes a third file with the lines that are unique to fileA. NOTE: Can be Memory intensive for large files.

spartan.utils.files.open_wo_comments(filePath, commentStr)[source]¶

Return a generator that acts like fileObj.next() but removes both commented lines and in-line comments.

Preserves line numbers.

spartan.utils.files.renameChrom_in_SAM(path)[source]¶
spartan.utils.files.rename_fasta_headers(in_path, out_path, header_func)[source]¶
GIVEN:
  • in_path = path to original fasta file
  • out_path = path to future altered fasta file
  • header_func = function to take a header line and return an altered string version of it
DOES:
  • Reads in in_path file one line at a time
  • If the line is a fasta header (starts with ‘>’) uses header_func logic to rearrange the header and writes out the changed line to out_path.
  • If not a header, writes same line out to out_path.
  • Closes both file objects.
RETURNS:
  • None
spartan.utils.files.tableFile2namedTuple(tablePath, sep='\t', headers=None)[source]¶

Returns namedTuple from table file using first row fields as col headers or a list supplied by user.

class spartan.utils.misc.Bunch(*args, **kwds)[source]¶

A dict like class to facilitate setting and access to tree-like data. Allows access to dictionary keys through ‘dot’ notation: “yourDict.key = value”.

coord_conversions.py¶

Mission: Provide code to convert start/stop coordinate pairs to and from specific conventions such as BED or GTF.

spartan.utils.annotations.coord_conversions.human_to_bed_chrom_start_stop(start, stop)[source]¶

Returns a tuple containing chromosome coords in BED convention.

Parameters:
  • start – first bp coordinate of subsequence (chromosome starts with 1 not 0).
  • stop – last bp coordinate of subsequence (chromosome starts with 1 not 0).
Returns:

bed_coords = (bed_start, bed_stop)

gffutils_helpers.py¶

spartan.utils.annotations.gffutils_helpers.load_gff3(gff3_path)[source]¶

Tries to load a gffutils database file first, if this fails, tries to create one, finally if the file is empty after it all, deletes the file.

Parameters:gff3_path – path to a gff3 file
Returns:gffutils database connection
spartan.utils.annotations.ensembl.gtf.no_common_names_in_ensembl_gtf(gtf_in, gtf_out)[source]¶

replace ‘gene_id’ value with ‘nearest_ref’ (wo the isoform tags) in the GTF file so that we can only have to know the AAEL, AGAP, CPIJ IDs to get our genes. Writes new file.
